content: american forces made one their most effective hits against islamic state nov. 15, when u.s. planes destroyed 116 tanker trucks used by terrorist organization transport stolen oil its financial lifeblood. american a-10 c-130 warplanes targeted group about 300 trucks near abu kamal, syria. given islamic state thought have just over 1,000 trucks its entire fleet, group 300 represented huge target u.s. planes. at pentagon news conference last wednesday, reporters wanted know why american forces did not take out more than 116 trucks. why not all 300, or something close that? u.s. official said american attackers simply ran out ammunition. "there were 300, i think, begin with, then hit 116. why didn't go back?" reporter asked operation inherent resolve spokesman col. steve warren. "frankly, aircraft expended 24 500-pound bombs, all their ammunition," warren answered. "so they -- they shot everything they had then they had go home." journalists had another question: if oil vitally important islamic state, why didn't u.s. hit tanker trucks long ago, given american anti-isis operation began september 2014? "if it's so important cut off oil shipments, critical revenue source isis, why did take so long take out 116 oil tanker trucks?" reporter asked. warren explained american officials were deeply worried about harming truck drivers, who were working islamic state but might not isis themselves. u.s. officials settled plan drop leaflets trucks about 45 minutes before raid, warning drivers an attack was coming, while u.s. pilots flew low passes over area. planning all took time. "this our first strike against tanker trucks," warren said. "we have been striking oil infrastructure targets since very beginning operation. what we found out was many our strikes were only minimally effective. we would strike pieces oil infrastructure were easily repaired." warren said u.s. officials conducted study decided focus islamic state's oil distribution network -- trucks. but problem was drivers. "we have not struck these trucks before," warren said. "we assessed these trucks, while although they being used operations support isil, truck drivers, themselves, [are] probably not members isil; they're probably just civilians. so we had figure out way around that. we're not business kill civilians, we're business stop isil -- defeat isil." american officials decided leaflet-and-buzz plan. "we spent some time developing ... leaflets, low pass," warren said. "we did some ... some strafe runs well -- kind shoo people away without harming them. so we had go through whole process one, determining whether or not we felt was our best interest strike these trucks. then once we determined that, yes, our interest strike these trucks, how do we go about ensuring we're able mitigate potential civilian casualties? these things take time." finally, when all work had been done, 300 islamic state trucks were found one place. was an inviting target. "these trucks were queued up," warren said. "they were sitting sort flat desert. there wasn't really anything recognizable road around. was just out there desert floor vicinity one these oil fields, one these oil facilities we've been striking. so they were queued up there waiting take their illicit oil. ... so these trucks were -- they were just sitting there, not moving." was an extraordinary opportunity take out somewhere between one-quarter one-third islamic state's entire truck fleet. after destroying 116, americans ran out ammunition. remaining 184 trucks were not destroyed. beyond out-of-ammo problem, reporters raised issue u.s. forces' extreme care avoiding civilian casualties. if american forces won't hit any target if there any fear any non-isis person might harmed, might not prolong time takes destroy islamic state, which killing civilians right left? "is there catch-22 about not striking civilians avoiding civilian casualties when, over past year, $50 million oil revenue generated has been going killing large number civilians?" reporter asked. "is there any risk avoiding civilian casualties actually prolonging more civilian casualties?" was very thoughtful question, warren conceded, an issue american war planners think about constantly. but warren didn't have an answer. "it's something we wrestle every day," he said.
title: byron york: u.s. ran out ammo attack isis trucks

"groundbreaking" study virtually ignored negatives from original research wasted few sentences plights children over 13 who reported "lower incomes" worse outcomes than had they never moved. hud officials also disregarded report's most critical observation that, "the mto experimental design cannot used conclusively establish childhood exposure better environment has causal effect long-term outcomes..." hud proceeding program that, after 15 years, researchers can show no conclusive proof works. there broader concerns. administration ignores aggressive pursuit methods reduce incidence single parent families, increase local educational opportunities, even though researchers recognize both solutions improving educational outcomes more important than incomes. hud even within its legal bounds? hud advancing mto program under its affirmatively furthering fair housing rule. yet, nothing fair housing act entitles hud transfer people gain income integration, nor engage many actions they taking under affh. continued below... hear no research, see no research hud department education believe poor student performance primarily result living concentrated areas poverty. remedy this, agency intends relocate low-income families better neighborhoods improve educational income outcomes. low-income family, seems like boon. who would not want move nicer area, especially if someone else paying it? but, conclude moving affluent areas best solution improve outcomes, hud had ignore volumes research findings prove location not prime driver scholastic ability. moving families locations where adults children have no friends or relatives areas they cannot afford, brings its own challenges. 2011 study, "the effects poverty academic achievement" concludes income mother's level education significant factors determining educational outcomes. content: department justice thursday formally asked u.s. supreme court overturn lower court's ruling block, part, trump administration's decision phase out deferred action childhood arrivals program. unusual step bypasses u.s. 9th circuit court appeals, which would have been normal move overturn u.s. district judge william alsup's ruling. last week, san francisco-based judge ordered trump administration renew parts daca start accepting renewal applications from those already part program while related lawsuits make their way through legal system. however, alsup did not demand new applications accepted. tuesday, attorney general jeff sessions said alsup's ruling "defies both law common sense" said department's supreme court request would happen by week's end. daca, which impacts roughly 700,000 people dubbed "dreamers," had been set expire march 5 after sessions announced september trump administration was rescinding obama-era program. congress now tasked passing legislation keep dreamers -- defined people who entered country minors -- from being at risk deportation.
title: justice department asks supreme court overturn daca ruling

content: crowd enveloped bus. daredevils scaled greased light poles. someone started lighting fireworks. was scene outside lincoln financial field boisterous eagles fans celebrated their 38-7 victory over minnesota vikings. celebration was much-needed, because philadelphia was losing elsewhere. thirty minutes into game, three miles away from stadium, workers at oil refinery owned by philadelphia energy solutions had been informed their jobs were jeopardy. reuters reported sunday company will soon file bankruptcy, its 1,100 employees might need start looking new line work. those jobs were secure years -- refinery was largest oil refining complex east coast. where can soon-to-be unemployed direct their anger? farmers flyover country bureaucrats washington, d.c. refinery going broke, reuters reports, largely because government. since 2012, philadelphia energy solutions has spent $800 million comply renewable fuels standard, which forces refiners blend certain amount biofuels into fuel supply or purchase credits. complying regulation was refiner's second-biggest cost after purchasing actual crude oil refine. eagles will head super bowl first sunday february. hopefully team can bring back win. philadelphia going need it.
title: flyover country farmers dc bureaucrats push philadelphia refinery into bankruptcy
meta_description: since 2012, philadelphia energy solutions has spent $800 million comply renewable fuels standard.

outlook, part two iraq destined become regional if not global superpower based richness its oil wealth. after all, young democracy sits atop world's second-biggest reserves high-quality petroleum. iraq's future seems bright indeed. regardless current political squabbling, oil-fueled iraqi economy continues grow rapidly. it's perennially rated one world's top ten fastest-growing economies, there's plenty room additional expansion. still, order see clearest view what iraqi economy may look like five or ten years, it's helpful take look at history iraq's oil industry well new oilfield technologies increasing iraqi production revenues. part one, we looked at history iraq's oil-based economy well political economical developments leading up rise saddam hussein his control nation's economy. now let's take look at iraq's oil industry current economic outlook, particularly what they mean value iraqi dinar, beginning turning point coalition invasion 2003 which ousted saddam. beginning end saddam u.s.-led invasion occupation iraq quickly ended saddam hussein's ruthless 30-year regime, was also beginning new era iraq's long-neglected oil industry. saddam his cronies gone, nation soon entered period unprecedented economic growth fueled by its booming oil industry. once dust settled after 2003 invasion, american, european middle eastern oil companies quickly arrived, ready business. there was much work done. oil industry infrastructure kurdish region northern iraq was relatively unscathed by actual fighting during war. still, oilfield equipment facilities there suffered from years neglect due shortage replacement parts new technologies made unavailable by years un-imposed trade embargo economic sanctions. southern central iraq, scene was different: between gulf war 1991 fighting during 2003, approximately 60% oil production refinery facilities those regions were damaged. apart from impact economic sanctions war, saddam himself stunted country's oil industry even further by mandating reservoir-management policies which resulted lower production several years after his departure. wells were over-pumped, which some cases permanently reduced their future outflows. and, an attempt boost yields lagging because equipment maintenance issues, iraqi engineers reinjected excessive amounts low-end petroleum fractions back into ground. reinjection standard industry technique increasing well's output. however, iraqi petroleum engineers reinjected overly-viscous oil constituents back into some wells, which slowed output several years after saddam's departure. huge reserves compensate missteps regardless mismanagement under saddam, fact iraq's overall oil production has soared since his departure illustrates enormity iraq's reserves resiliency its industry. spite thirty years bungling, iraq has been steadily achieving higher oil production totals almost every year since saddam's demise. according conservative estimates dating 2001, iraq believed have at least 145 billion barrels oil remaining tapped, several more-recent estimates have nearly doubled figure. geographically, most iraq's known petroleum reserves lie belt runs roughly north south along eastern side country. iraq has at least 10 fields known "super giants" (minimum 5 billion barrels each) another 25+ "giant" fields (minimum 1 billion barrels each). leading petroleum engineers have indicated southeastern iraq's cluster super-giant fields world's largest concentration such fields, accounting about 80% country's reserves. remaining 20% known reserves found northern region kirkuk, khanaqin mosul. and, there seems plenty room more oil discoveries - iraq unique because only tiny fraction its known reserves under development, even though already exports enormous amounts crude oil. development continues, more oil gushes forth. fact, since 1925 only about 2,200 wells have been drilled throughout iraq. comparison, approximately one million wells have already been drilled state texas alone. iraq also "full gas." country's proven reserves natural gas approximately 115 trillion cubic feet, which fifth-largest world. about two-thirds these known gas reserves located southern iraq, rest north. back work any event, soon saddam was gone iraqi oil industry began returning normal. during years between 2003 2008, iraq was busily repairing both its civilian infrastructure damaged by war well upgrading its long-neglected oilfields. 2008 iraqi government announced new plan work world's largest oil companies - shell, exxonmobil, bp total, who were original partners iraq petroleum company (ipc) dating back 1929. plan was quickly replaced by an even larger, more comprehensive plan develop iraq's oilfields. 2009 iraqi ministry oil formally awarded service contracts these original "big oil" companies well several other international firms including chevron. oilfields under contract development include iraq's "super-giant" fields: halfaya, majnoon, west qurna, rumaila. china national petroleum corporation (cnpc) bp won contract develop rumaila field, which iraq's largest single field. result these agreements iraq was able increase its production dramatically. by 2009 iraq had risen from near-zero production at end saddam's reign become world's twelfth-largest producer. 2010 u.s. government allocated $2 billion help develop modernize iraqi oil gas industry, although its direct involvement managing industry ended 2008. by end 2012 iraqi oil production had risen nearly 3.5 million barrels per day. then, 2014 another milestone was reached: production averaged 3.6 million barrels per day, level not achieved since 1979. 2014 brief glitch arose when kurdistan regional government (krg) seized control several northern oilfields dispute central government baghdad regarding revenues. fortunately, early 2015 was at least temporarily resolved, oil flows have returned normal since then. newer technologies boost iraqi output 2015, iraqi oil production already benefiting from new technologies which had been unavailable during years un trade embargo. during past few years these newer technologies have been introduced into iraq by international oil companies have been using such methods increase oilfield yields other countries. given iraq's huge reserves, nation's oil industry will certainly gain maximum benefit from these technologies. most important new technologies directional drilling hydraulic fracturing, both which promise help boost iraqi production exports significantly. directional drilling before 1970s, most wells were drilled vertically. is, hole was drilled straight downward until reached oil, or not. then, 1973 several drilling companies developed techniques slant drilling, which was an early form directional drilling allowed hole drilled at slight angle. directional drilling equipment allows drill bit move curving line rather than straight line, so can snake its way around underground obstacles such unusually hard rock formations. fact, given enough depth, wells can drilled horizontally, is, parallel surface land above. first practical benefit directional drilling allows drillers reach oil reservoirs several miles away from site drilling rig. current technology allows drillers drill far 6 miles away laterally. so, example, directional drilling allows land-based rigs drill offshore locations, which significantly reduces production expenses. and, oil located under steep mountains can likewise tapped from nearby flatlands. most importantly iraq, directional drilling allows producers increase length underground pipe exposed reservoir. instead simply having very end pipe inserted into an oil reservoir, directional drilling fairly long perforated section pipe placed contact oil. critically important ensuring high flows once well completed, since oil can sucked through much larger surface area. iraq directional drilling enables producers overcome sluggish flows which had resulted from saddam's policy over-drawing oil from wells then reinjecting thick, undesirable residues back into ground hopes obtaining short-term increases flow, mentioned above. and, directional drilling also makes possible multiple wellheads draw oil from single drilling site, so extended length perforated pipe exposed oil reservoir means greater yields. likewise, directional drilling also allows single wellhead draw oil and/or gas from within several different geologic strata (layers rock) at different depths, something which impossible older perpendicular drilling methods. introduction directional drilling technologies has helped iraq dramatically increase its production, these technologies hold promise even greater yields future. hydraulic fracturing hydraulic fracturing, sometimes also called fracking, method stimulating wells produce more oil. effectiveness fracking was discovered during series experiments 1947, first commercial application came 1950. although some communities u.s. have debated use fracking our domestic production, iraq practice potential godsend because may allow oil producers significantly increase their wells' outputs. water containing suspension sand other constituents injected under high pressure down into well order create cracks oil-bearing rock. these cracks allow oil flow more freely within underground reservoir, therefore more can extracted. hydraulic fracture created underground by pumping fracturing fluid into wellbore order increase underground pressure enough crack rock. rock cracks, fracturing fluid continues onward, extending cracking further further. fracking equipment can operate at pressures flow rates up 15,000 pounds pressure per square inch (psi) inbound flows fracking fluid high 100 barrels per minute. sand other materials called proppants added fracking fluid order "prop open" cracks already created, so they won't close while oil flowing outward. these propped-open fractures allow oil gas trapped within rock more easily flow outward. it's been estimated fracking increases oil production by an average about 17%, natural gas production by an average 45%. most importantly, when used together fracking directional drilling have synergistic effect - yields both together may substantially higher than if each were used separately. outlook given its huge oil reserves long-term commitments by international oil companies develop its oil gas fields, iraq certain have bright economic future. measured by its ever-increasing volume oil exports, country's oil industry has fully recovered from damage mismanagement suffered during saddam hussein's reign. notwithstanding iraq's already-known reserves, seems likely recent new exploration efforts by oil companies will lead an even greater tally iraq's oil wealth. it's also important note iraq isn't just blessed large reserves, also happens geologic formations holding iraq's oil much more accessible drilling than they most countries, which means costs extracting oil much lower. significant because iraq can profitably produce petroleum at prices less than $40 per barrel. contrast, u.s. shale oil costs between $90 $100 per barrel produce, even most cost-effective wells texas generally require global oil price at least $40 per barrel order profitable. so, iraq can afford pump sell oil at prices below those most other producing nations. these production advantages have been visible during recent saudi arabian oil-production war designed bankrupt u.s. shale-oil producers. while oil producers u.s. elsewhere have been severely impacted by saudis' overproduction, iraq continues produce profitably. oil drives iraqi dinar given world's insatiable appetite oil gas, iraq's dominant supply role likely become even stronger going forward. although it's difficult predict future certainty, seems likely sometime near future iraq will grow into regional international energy super-power based its rich reserves. fact, iraq seems on-track replace saudi arabia region's wealthiest, most-developed nation within next few years. what does mean dinar? nation's economy, well value its currency, depends its natural resources. iraq's exceptionally large oil reserves like "money bank," available meet young democracy's needs continues grow. eventually value iraqi dinar should rise reflect true value country's oil wealth. seems likeliest occur once central bank iraq (cbi) frees dinar from artificially-low value placed 2003 following darkest days saddam hussein's regime. when occurs, strength iraq's economy will rapidly become obvious all observers worldwide, not simply those few individuals who have taken time research it. any event, knowledge key success. learn more about status iraqi content: subscribe canada free press free majority inspectors general find themselves unable perform their duties audit federal government government inspectors generals describe atmosphere restricted access inspectors general (yes, that's plural) considered watchdogs government. their jobs primarily focus "uncovering waste, fraud, mismanagement", which an important function keep government programs agencies check. serious breach trust evident, therefore, when 47 73 inspectors general pen letter congress describing "serious limitations access records." that's 64% total watchdogs who express such concerns. can read letter here: letter takes aim at primarily three agencies: general at peace corps, environmental protection agency, department justice. these inspectors general "recently faced restrictions their access certain records available their agencies were needed perform their oversight work critical areas." restrictions were not limited just those inspectors general; hence overwhelming need pen letter congress. inspectors general described how other "inspectors general have, from time time, faced similar obstacles their work, whether claim some other law or principle trumped clear mandate ig act or by agency's imposition unnecessarily burdensome administrative conditions access. even when we ultimately able toresolve these issues senior agency leadership, process often lengthy, delays our work, diverts time attention from substantive oversight activities. plainly not what congress intended when passed ig act. inspector general act 1978 clear. pertinent statute relates access section ss6: authority inspector general; information assistance from federal agencies; unreasonable refusal; office space equipment. patently states: (a) addition authority otherwise provided by act, each inspector general, carrying out provisions act, authorized-- (1) have access all records, reports, audits, reviews, documents, papers, recommendations, or other material available applicable establishment which relate programs operations respect which inspector general has responsibilities under act full text law can found here: letter congress was addressed honorable darrell issa, honorable thomas r. carper, honorable elijah cummings, honorable tom coburn. what made letter particularly notable, however, was its size scope. darrell issa described, "i've never seen letter like this, my folks have checked--there has never been letter even dozen igs complaining. majority all inspectors general saying not just examples they gave, but government wide, they see pattern making them unable do their job." reading official website inspectors general, one can see they pride themselves service, "whose primary responsibilities, american public, detect prevent fraud, waste, abuse, violations law promote economy, efficiency effectiveness operations federal government." fact majority inspectors general find themselves unable perform their duties audit federal government quite troubling, because another example "most transparent administration" choosing willfully cloak themselves secrecy. stonewalling very agents--who have duty american people keep government check--is another tactical abuse power. alan joel has been practicing cpa nyc more than 40 years. he loves liberty writes politics taxes at his popular blog, <url> content: like many conservatives who live amongst those who believe they own franchise enlightened thinking, i have often been asked how world i could have voted (fill progressive blank) like george w. bush president. remarkably, answer question one seems have eluded most these deep thinkers. "you mean how could i have voted george w. bush--as opposed hypocritical scold like al gore, or self-aggrandizing blowhard like john kerry?" i invariably respond. unless you've has been living an alternative universe, you're well aware avalanche criticism directed at donald trump from all quarters, liberal conservative, including latest hypocritical screed by mitt romney. yet despite criticism, virtually everyone engaged ignores essential reality attends every election: context everything. other words, whatever one feels about donald trump, or any other candidate matter, ultimate question answer cannot postponed indefinitely, donald trump--running against whom? unfortunately, john kerry remained true his appetite power, thus american public remains afflicted secretary state who needs "additional evaluation" undertaken before he can decide if wholesale systematic slaughter christians middle east constitutes "genocide." man who, when informed former gitmo detainee had returned terrorism, epitomized utter clueless entire obama administration's foreign policy. "he's not supposed doing that," kerry stated. being said, there little doubt my mind commander-in-chief al gore or john kerry would have been worse leaders by several orders magnitude. gore had decency take his global warming hustle into private sector, where he made millions selling christian-like dispensations known "carbon credits" terminally gullible. unfortunately like his father, george w. believed maintaining comity his democrat detractors was apparently more important defending most momentous decision any commander-in-chief must make. reneging his no new taxes pledge accommodate democrats--who savaged him return--probably cost george h.w. bush 1992 election. george w.'s flaccid response reid company gave us democratically-controlled congress 2006--and paved way rise barack obama 2008. let's clear here. neither ringing endorsement what bush accomplished, nor knock what i perceived his major failings, foremost which was allowing democrats co-opt iraq war narrative without any substantive pushback. when american men women harm's way, allowing slanderous hack like harry reid declare war "lost" even before ultimately successful surge was completed, was an unconscionable unnecessary surrender. pretty clear eight years obama administration's effort "fundamentally transform united states america" into socialist utopian paradise, third world underpinning millions illegals represent, has enraged millions americans. maybe even point, so many trump's critics point out, where anger frustration has completely supplanted anything resembling rational thinking. anger frustration about what? how about gop establishment has made an utter mockery their base's support now process going after base's preferred candidate kind vigor viciousness they have never directed at at barack obama or hillary clinton? moreover, what world do they think would happen if they purposely orchestrate brokered convention where none current presidential candidates get nomination? they have know number conservatives who stayed home when milquetoast mitt "polited" his way defeat would dwarfed by number who would stay home if an establishment gop candidate were force-fed base. thus an inescapable conclusion arises: establishment gop would tolerate president hillary clinton maintain their control party--even if they run party into dustbin history result. would same hillary clinton, who believes rule law applies everyone else but her her husband. same hillary clinton who left four americans die benghazi then lied about video being cause their demise when her own communications her daughter, egyptian prime minister hisham kandil libyan president night attack indicated she knew otherwise. women who still can't explain at very least how highly-classified emails "migrated" from wholly secure self-contained government servers her personal one. woman no discernible accomplishments senator, track record colossal failure secretary state. woman who successfully used sexist card bash every republican, until trump came along threw right back her predator-enabling face. make no mistake: not an endorsement donald trump. i'm not big fan palookaville style politics, or mud-wrestling into which republican primary season has devolved. but if trump does make finish line, hillary his opponent, then what? if comes down these two, who do want picking next supreme court justice--or three? who do want formulating immigration policy? who has better vision our terminally-underperforming economy? who do want defending america against islamist terror, iranian nuclear ambitions russian chinese military expansionism? who do want restoring american exceptionalism, someone who might believe it, or someone who clearly doesn't? electorate has long been forced choose between "lesser two evils," there little doubt may very well prove most pernicious choice modern history. but remains choice nonetheless, maybe most important one very long time. thus behooves every would-be voter keep context mind, no matter how down dirty 2016 presidential campaign becomes. fact, context all ultimately matters.
title: context everything
authors: arnold ahlert, because without america, there no free world.
meta_description: news, politics, editorials, commentary, canada free press, because without america, there no free world

content: united states has slashed its contribution un relief works agency palestinian refugees by more than $65 million, but still gave agency $60 million. that's $60 million too much. unrwa has become poster child u.n. bureaucratic bloat, mission creep, twisted morality. unrwa was founded 1949 help palestinian refugees displaced by israel's war independence. even decision was questionable. after all, putting israel's creation aside, 1940s alone, wars created more than 40 million refugees. there was world war ii, course, but 1947 partition india also displaced 14 million persons created millions refugees. wake israel's creation, arab states expelled hundreds thousands their jews. why u.n. created united nations high commissioner refugees permanent agency charged refugee assistance protection. individual palestinian arab families suffered dislocation tragedy, but they were hardly alone. they were alone, however, having u.n. agency created cater specifically them. still, when u.n. created unrwa, was meant temporary agency address temporary problem. once resettled palestinian refugees, its job was done was shut its doors forever dissolve. 1951 report un general assembly, unrwa reported, "there must firm goal terminating relief operations. sustained relief operations inevitably contain germ human deterioration." was right, but arab state rejectionism got way. arab states like egypt, syria, iraq quickly concluded they could use unrwa perpetuate problem, undercut normalization israel, transform an aid agency into weapon against israel. rest history. both current unrwa commissioner general pierre krahenbuhl unrwa spokesman chris gunness were born years after unrwa was meant dissolve. nor does unrwa's track record make worth saving. while unhcr has resettled refugees allowed them get their lives, unrwa has actively undercut settlement. has embraced unique definition refugee differs unhcr used everywhere else world. consider: if india pakistan used same definition refugee from their partition unrwa embraces, there would more than 100 million refugees south asia today. unrwa has helped make palestinians largest per capita recipient aid earth, but has least show it. problem isn't just waste money, however. almost quarter-century after palestinian authority began, unrwa has eroded rather than supported foundations good governance. after all, if unrwa promises take care housing, education, support, why shouldn't both palestinian authority their sometime-partner hamas spend money terror pensions, terror tunnels, an arsenal rockets? add into mix unrwa incompetence: schools used arsenals, school books teaching incitement, unrwa employees moonlighting bomb makers, terror recruitment unrwa high schools problem even worse. unrwa denials complicity such activities, if taken at face value, just acknowledgment its own poor oversight. it's long past time cut off unrwa ask unhcr take over. palestinians deserve an apolitical agency rather than an amplifier radicalism waste. unrwa has become cancer not only those who seek peace reconciliation, but also entire un system. unrwa 1951 was right. permanence not virtue; it's an impediment. michael rubin (@mrubin1971) contributor washington examiner's beltway confidential blog. he resident scholar at american enterprise institute former pentagon official. if would like write an op-ed washington examiner, please read our guidelines submissions here.
title: us support unrwa has gone long enough
meta_description: when u.n. created unrwa, was meant temporary agency address temporary problem.

content: subscribe canada free press free chance learn about practice - limited manner under controlled conditions - optimal steering wheel control, vision anticipation, well some obstacle avoidance emergency braking tactics both straight line curves mitsubishi winter driving event helps teach control snow winter may its way outsoon, but there's still enough "old person" around ensure snowy canadian roads will challenging at least few more weeks. means there's still ample opportunity more skid-related fender benders before spring springs grass starts rizzing. end, mitsubishi canada has been road well, bringing some professional drivers some their outlander suv/crossovers alberta not only showcase "crummy weather capabilities" their vehicles but give some handy tips attendees who find themselves oot aboot when white stuff sticks. i love these events; they're not only fun but they can help "navigate neige" more confidence skill. i did similar type thing couple years back when ford came through will always show up such events because can never have too much practice - it's real hoot sliding around snowy open area someone else's vehicle (and they treat really nicely, too). so was mitsubishi their folk, armed squadron outlanders, came through calgary last saturday last leg their three stop tour wild rose country. they were accompanied well by representatives from morrisport advanced driving, group personable driving experts whom i've worked before well. event kicked off short presentation by morrisport's lawrence howlett, who outlined what we could expect from two hour session then gave us some insight into such issues proper seating position, physics vehicle control benefits such technologies traction control abs, well mitsubishi's systems all wheel control there actually two such systems - well, one's an enhancement other - available outlander given mitsubishi's legendary record when comes rallying, company appears have gotten technology down pat. basic awc sends torque, when vehicle's electronic brain deems necessary, from front rear axle help ensure good traction when front wheels (the base model front driver - like many, many others suv/crossover market these days) start losing traction. "super all wheel control" that's available gt trim level ups ante by adding torque vectoring between front left right wheels well, even better control when push comes shove. both systems work well, we noticed during driving part event, but bottom line always proverbial nut behind wheel, which meant driving part experience was even more important because gave us chance actually put words into practice. so we did! event, held at calgary's winsport complex (aka canada olympic park), had us navigate slalom course initially, starting slowly building up speed we got comfortable. thanks fresh snow was plenty slippery, which course worked benefit exercise, but combination mitsubishi's awc systems expert guidance meant very few cones were clobbered. from there, we did an acceleration braking course - basically straight line between cones during which we peeled out much possible snow (surprisingly peelable, thanks mits technology), barrelled toward braking zone, then tromped pedal. first time was kind tentative, then we got faster more aggressive brake pedal showcase not only outlanders' performance but also show us difference between braking without using anti-lock brake system. i've always been opinion if traction control and/or abs comes then aren't doing your job driver, but sometimes it's nice have electronic robots hand just case. especially true these days; my first car abs was an original generation infiniti q45 first generation abs traction control was more annoying than useful, but those days appear long gone technology has marched onward. from there, we went "fork road" event where we went like bat out hell toward said fork - laid out again cones - instructor waiting till last minute tell us if we should take left or right fork, or stay middle stand brakes. not only taught us listen pay attention, also helped showcase benefits looking far down road ahead possible so you're ready whatever might happen front you. focus, should be, was importance smoothness behind steering wheel. not just smoothness wheel itself, though course that's critical, but smoothness pedals well. sure, nannies awc can help lot, but bottom line always pilot command is, indeed, command should take those responsibilities seriously. continued below... reminds me line movie "contact," where young girl heroine trying find people talk her ham radio. her dad tells her "small moves," meaning basically being smooth gentle tuning knob would help. did: she ended up an alien-designed space transport! it's same driving. sure, there times when panic stop or swerve might necessary, but lion's share your time behind wheel will better more efficient if keep your eyes peeled conditions around (and far ahead can see) so that, if do need make some kind course correction, can do smaller, more controlled - smoother - moves. racers such morrisport guys know practice they helped attendees understand concept before unleashing us wreak our own special havoc snowy lot. bottom line event gave those us who were there chance learn about practice - limited manner under controlled conditions - optimal steering wheel control, vision anticipation, well some obstacle avoidance emergency braking tactics both straight line curves. can do your own any reasonably large, snow-covered parking lot. sure, may not have expert guidance we had during mitsubishi's event, or bunch cones lay out, but any practice good practice if can learn control your vehicle better by doing few donuts after mall has closed day, you'll more confident more skilled when push really does come slide real world. besides, it's fun! jim publishes technofile magazine. jim an affiliate automobile journalists association canada his careers have included journalist, technology retailer, video store pioneer, syndicated columnist; he does biweekly column cbc radio one's business network. jim can reached at: [email protected] older articles by jim bray please adhere our commenting policy avoid being banned. privately owned website, we reserve right remove any comment ban any user at any time.comments contain spam, advertising, vulgarity, threats violence, racism, anti-semitism, or personal or abusive attacks other users may removed result ban.-- follow these instructions registering

content: school choice often compared many things, but sen. john kennedy, r-la., came up new one tuesday: mayonnaise. "i can go down my over-priced capitol hill grocery afternoon choose among about six different types mayonnaise," kennedy said. "how come i can't do my kid school?" well, that's new one. comparisons between grocery stores school choice fairly common comparison. if, example, food stamp recipients were only allowed use their benefits at nearest grocery store, there would outrage. low-income families would stuck shopping at low-quality convenience stores while wealthy would free shop at grocery stores their choice. kennedy's comparison wasn't too far out there, but was funny nonetheless. not everyone was amused by kennedy's quip. "education not mayonnaise, day we choose treat public education like marketing our condiments we have given up our kids," sen. chris murphy, d-conn., said later hearing. kennedy, apparently not one mince words or spread them slices whole-grain bread, produced another giggle-worthy moment at senate subcommittee hearing when he asked secretary education betsy devos, "you're aware, i'm sure, some people don't like because support vouchers charter schools?" devos took answer stride, replying grin, said, "i'm peripherally aware that, yes." jason russell contributors editor washington examiner.
title: sen. john kennedy compares school choice mayonnaise

content: super pac committed ending chris christie's presidential campaign calling quits, claiming new jersey governor has done much their work them. former rep. tom tancredo, r-colo., created "stop chris christie" pac last november. tancredo reportedly said at time group's purpose was defeat christie's campaign since governor "no true conservative." but recent statement posted group's facebook page, treasurer tom bjorklund said group had notified federal election commission would shutting down pac by sept. 25 due "miserable showing candidate question." "our committee believes mr. christie has already performed service stopping his campaign spirit, (without or aid) even if not by letter law," bjorklund wrote laura sinram, senior campaign finance analyst at fec. bjorklund's letter sinram was response notification issued by fec july group was violation federal election rules using christie's name without procuring his permission. two other outside groups associated republican hopefuls carly fiorina donald trump have also been flagged by fec recently using candidates' names without their approval. "stop chris christie"'s website has already been shut down bjorklund says they will spend next couple weeks communicating vendors obtaining closing invoices from individuals who assisted committee's formation. according fec records, anti-christie pac had only raised $1,350 by mid-year filing deadline total operating expenditure $8.74. christie's popularity has plummeted his home state where voters have grown increasingly frustrated, claiming he prioritizing his presidential run over his responsibilities governor. two-term governor barely made into first republican primary debate and, although he set take stage again second debate sept. 19, recent polls early primary states place him bottom half gop field. polling data from realclearpolitics currently shows christie averaging 5.3 percent support among republican primary voters new hampshire just 2 percent iowa. spokesperson christie's camp told washington examiner pac's closure simply an attempt dodge an investigation by fec.
title: 'stop christie' pac quits, says candidate did its job them
meta_description: pac's purpose was reportedly defeat christie's campaign since governor 'no true conservative.'

content: author michael wolff insisted friday he interviewed president trump three hours during campaign while he was president preparation his newly released book fire fury: inside trump white house. "i absolutely spoke president. whether he realized was an interview or not, i don't know. but certainly wasn't off record," wolff said nbc friday morning his book was being released. "i spoke him after inauguration, yes. i had spoken -- i've spent three hours president over course campaign at white house so my window into donald trump pretty significant," he added. "i spoke people who spoke president daily, sometimes minute by minute, basis." "i am certainly, absolutely every way comfortable everything reported book." - @michaelwolffnyc validity his reporting 'fire fury' b <url>/3u3yo8i2fz-- today (@todayshow) january 5, 2018 wolff's new book trump has been called into question by white house reporters errors throughout his story. however, author maintained tell-all book accurate he has proof his interviews few hundred sources. "i work like every journalist works so i have recordings, i have notes. i am certainly absolutely every way comfortable everything i've reported," wolff said. "i've written many books. i've written millions upon millions words. i don't think there has ever been one correction." wolff said he stands "absolutely everything book, 100 percent" does not plan release notes or recordings attacked trump's calling his stories into question. "my credibility being questioned by man who has less credibility than perhaps anyone who has walked earth at point," he added. he also said trump's aides have had increasingly remind trump about current events because he has become increasingly forgetful. "it used -- i know people would point out beginning, would every 25 or 30 minutes, he would get same three stories repeated. now it's same three stories every 10 minutes," wolff said. "he's lost it."
title: michael wolff rejects trump claim: 'i absolutely spoke president'

content: venezuelan president nicolas maduro told president trump stop "meddling" his country's affairs friday after u.s. implemented sanctions against south american country. "enough meddling ... go home, donald trump. get out venezuela," maduro yelled televised speech. "get your dirty hands out here." socialist leader's condemnation comes day after white house imposed sanctions chief judge seven members venezuela's supreme court. move was intended punishment invalidating opposition-led congress earlier year, move was later rescinded. maduro's administration has targeted street protesters since november an attempt shut down any opposition his government. "the extreme positions government just starting off only confirmed discriminatory, racist, xenophobic genocidal nature u.s. elites against humanity its own people, which has now been heightened by new administration which asserts white anglo-saxon supremacy," venezuelan government said statement.

content: university alabama, public university tuscaloosa, ala., has yellow speech rating according foundation individual rights education's campus free speech rating system. institutions which hold 'yellow light speech code rating' defined ones have "at least one ambiguous policy too easily encourages administrative abuse arbitrary application." university alabama has three policies egregiously violate students' first amendment rights. those policies deal university space, event advertisement, event planning. students can only use university space if an event "in accordance priorities designated area." alabama also restricts where students can pass out advertisements an approved event administration requires all advertisements "good taste." administration makes final rulings what qualifies good taste. "things like ground use restrictions really damage ability students share ideas freely openly," zach warren, president university alabama's young americans liberty chapter, told red alert politics. "on our campus any hand outs must approved so when we hand out pocket constitutions those technically have submitted weeks advance approval." these policies allow administrative overreach enable administration ignore students' rights free expression campus. another example yellow light policy alabama's event planning policy, which requires students submit an "online event planning form" seven ten business days before an event. an event requires such steps include 5ks, parades, demonstrations or marches. university's opinion, these policies designed avoid scheduling conflicts allocate resources effectively. taylor bryant, university alabama's director communications, told red alert politics an email these policies supposedly help "ensure safety our students campus community offers all campus-affiliated parties same opportunities without disrupting university's ability provide its essential services teaching learning." "our grounds use permit policy allows campus affiliates request space meets their needs helps university staff coordinate appropriate campus resources (security, grounds keeping, etc.) avoid scheduling conflicts," bryant stated. these policies have been abused by ua past seen october 2016 when ua imposed $7,000 security fee ua college republicans chapter bringing milo yiannopoulos campus. after initially expecting fee $1,000, ua continually increased amount required security fee event drew near. only after experiencing significant pushback from students did university rescind fee allow event go planned. "while policies like those at university alabama not unique, what makes them especially egregious layers upon layers red tape university puts students exercise their first amendment rights," said alexander staudt, director free speech at young americans liberty. "whether restricting space-use based priorities area or requiring 'good taste' stamp approval from administration advertisements, these policies unconstitutional. public universities, such ua, obligated maximize breadth availability speech, ideas, knowledge." tyler cochran studies political science religion at missouri state university. he media ambassador missouri state chair young americans liberty.
title: code yellow: university alabama places limits free speech
meta_keywords: ['campus speech codes', 'campus free speech', 'red alert politics', 'alabama', 'college']
meta_description: university alabama has three policies egregiously violate students' first amendment rights; those policies deal university...

content: democrats both off house select committee benghazi skewered an 800-page report made public tuesday by panel republicans presenting no new facts about sept. 11, 2012 terror attack. aside from questioning 81 witnesses had never before been interviewed by congressional investigators, select committee reviewed thousands previously undisclosed documents drew new conclusions about administration's handling terror attack. below nine things benghazi committee uncovered its 25-month investigation. email server hillary clinton's use private email account server was unknown previous congressional committees looked into circumstances surrounding benghazi. dozens emails discussing attack libya were hidden server, including some shed light how clinton her aides initially sought take "ownership" libyan invasion. when news clinton's private email use first broke march 2015, benghazi committee seemingly entered new, highly-politicized phase. her server scandal took off just she was preparing enter presidential race, injecting partisan vitriol into an investigation had proceeded relative quiet up point. examination clinton's private emails led committee previously unknown force had helped shape secretary state's policy run-up benghazi: sidney blumenthal. blumenthal behind scenes divisive political operative who was barred from working obama administration, sidney blumenthal provided unvetted intelligence clinton about libya even he attempted cultivate business opportunities war-torn country. blumenthal appeared before committee june 2015, where his commercial dealings potential conflicts interest were questioned closed-door interview. at issue was fact partisan figure had direct line secretary state matters sensitive regime change libya. fact, many blumenthal's missives clinton have since been marked classified by state department. extent blumenthal's influence was not uncovered previous investigations benghazi. hillary's upcoming visit select committee revealed clinton herself was set visit libya weeks after sept. 11, 2012 attack, plan was scrapped after benghazi raid. scheduled trip was one many instances highlighted state department's severe misreading security situation libya. clinton's planned visit had implications ambassador chris stevens, who was laying groundwork her travel when he was killed attack gregory hicks, deputy chief mission libya, told committee investigators ambassador's stay benghazi was "absolutely" related clinton's visit. permanent post stevens had journeyed benghazi work "deliverable" clinton's upcoming trip, select committee revealed. his work deliverable involved preparing proposal turn temporary diplomatic compound benghazi into permanent post. "[w]e had begun process developing political rationale having permanent post benghazi," hicks testified. report said state department discussions benghazi's deteriorating security situation earlier 2012 framed outbreaks violence "anomalies" officials forged ahead plan establish diplomatic presence coastal libyan city. given his now-famous affection people libya, stevens was an advocate plan. gadhafi rescuers select committee discovered group "most u.s. government personnel did not even know existed" helped americans trapped at cia annex escape morning sept. 12. "this group, ironically, had close ties former gadhafi regime -- very regime united states had helped remove from power," report said. report credited group, which was affiliated deposed dictator muammar gadhafi, sparing "dozens lives." according select committee's findings, cia agent who had never previously been interviewed by other congressional investigators facilitated evacuation gadhafi militia's help. cia was "reluctant" allow committee interview agent. "libyan military intelligence," group was known, arrived motorcade 50 vehicles transport state department cia personnel under siege at annex airport, where they could evacuated tripoli. some those vehicles were fitted machine guns others had secure fixtures would allow fleet escape americans while taking fire. cia agent question had contacted libyan military intelligence help after receiving referral from "helpless" contingent local police officers who had been tapped secure annex but proved unable do so. committee focused fact that, all state department's focus cultivating relationships burgeoning libyan government, only people who tried help americans were those cast aside by agency. "[s]ome very individuals united states had helped remove from power during libyan revolution were only libyans came assistance united states night benghazi attacks," report said. uniform problems marines rota, spain who were awaiting orders head benghazi experienced hours delay due concern about what they were wearing, one witness told select committee. after c-130 planes reached base marines, who were part fleet antiterrorism security team known fast force, prepared take off tripoli, three-hour delay ensued due deliberations about whether company members should wear their military uniforms or civilian clothes, whether they would permitted carry weapons. "[w]e were told multiple times change what we were wearing," platoon commander testified. "there was also some talk whether or not we could carry our personal weapons." commander testified he advocated his team allowed carry weapons because they were headed into "a very violent thing going ground." all, marines were forced change their clothes four times before they were deployed libya, according testimony. gen. carter ham, the-commander africom, told committee he did not learn uniform changes "until after fact" even then could not pinpoint reason three-hour delay rota. delay had come after c-130s took six hours arrive from germany despite receiving orders fly there at once. "the fact nearly twenty-four hours elapsed until those [fast] forces actually arrived tripoli reinforce security there belies expectations american people u.s. military can will move expeditiously," committee report said. discussions over whether force fast marines wear civilian clothes took place washington, where high-level officials expressed concerns about military show force libya. "[t]hey wanted minimize signature looked like big military invasion, big military arrival there," one witness testified. rather than increase safety marines en route benghazi, "the benefit having fast platoon wear civilian clothing was cater unexpressed libyan government concerns about military appearances," report said. according report, patrick kennedy, state department's undersecretary management, suggested fast platoon shed their uniforms during key white house meeting night attack. white house meeting around 7:30 p.m. washington time night raid, high-level officials gathered via secure video teleconference discuss events unfolding benghazi. neither president obama nor defense secretary leon panetta was present. clinton attended, well several her top aides kennedy. meeting was not convened until four hours after attack began. sean smith stevens had already died. "despite secretary [of defense]'s expectation assets he ordered deploy would move fast possible order respond, individuals who participated white house meeting, nevertheless, felt need 'work through' assets secretary had already ordered deploy," report said. republicans committee noted meeting participants became "surprisingly unable recall details" about what was discussed night when they were questioned by investigators. although an email sent by pentagon's chief staff just before conference indicated forces were "spinning up" preparing deploy, report indicated "it was clear by end white house meeting no forces were going benghazi." diplomatic niceties administration officials placed tremendous importance way their actions would perceived libya during attack, report found. example, military assets europe were not allowed take off benghazi until administration received clearance from libyan government enter libyan airspace. but process was lengthy required libyan government official receive paperwork request person when no such official was duty overnight attacks were unfolding. before raid even began, diplomatic concerns prevented state department from greenlighting higher security profile ambassador benghazi even though conditions country warranted one. 'no connection' cairo weeks after benghazi attack, administration attempted link violence libya relatively peaceful protest cairo hours earlier had erupted over an inflammatory youtube clip. internal correspondence obtained by committee suggests that, rather than receiving conflicting intelligence matter, administration knew within hours attack benghazi had little do demonstrations cairo. "for [press] guidance, if pressed whether we see connection between these two. we have no information regarding connection between these incidents." nuland wrote events benghazi cairo within two hours administration learning benghazi attack. kennedy told congressional staff subsequent briefing benghazi attack had no relation cairo protest because demonstrators cairo had no weapons simply spray-painted some illustrations near cairo embassy.
title: nine biggest benghazi committee discoveries
meta_description: new conclusions were made about administration's handling terror attack.
